text: hey study abroad students mark your with
Walters world and we're in Madrid Spain
a very hot spot for study abroad
students wanted to learn Spanish are
just enjoying some of the Europe and the
thing is I've studied abroad in many
places I study abroad in Australia
Finland Argentina Portugal all kinds of
places and I had lots of options to stay
and I never knew which one would be the
right one for me so what I have here for
you today are basically how you should
choose where you should live when you
study abroad so I'm gonna do is give you
the pros and cons of three basic study
abroad living options the first one
living with a family now it can be great
if you're living with a family because
one you get an automatic you know tour
guide you get language classes everyday
you get to learn about the culture and
all kinds of stuff and you have somebody
that's looking out for you now the bad
side of that is usually you have more
rules when you live with families okay
and also sometimes you feel obligated to
hang out with them when you want to go
out with your friends and of course it
might cramp your style you're looking to
meet a a chico or a chica these kind of
things but in general I find if your
goal to study abroad is sort of learn
the language and the culture staying
with a host family is the most important
thing okay I went to Argentina I live
with a host family that's how I learned
the language when I went to Brazil I
live with a host family because it
helped me to understand the language and
the people better so I understood when
they made their jokes and they spoke the
language okay so that's the first thing
families you got that choice second
thing you can rent an apartment now the
thing is you can rent apartment with one
by yourself too you can rent it with
other study abroad students which is
kind of a more popular thing or three
rent an apartment with some locals now
when I can allow you renting an
apartment with locals is very difficult
to find okay so it's not really an
option unless you're staying for a whole
year and most of time you've already
signed a lease for a year anyway when
you move in so that's not really a
realistic option sometimes the second
one we look at is living with by
yourself hey you get the freedom live on
your own
do your own thing things like that
though it is a lot more difficult to
meet friends and meet people if you're
living on your own so that's kind of a
drawback but you do have the freedom
there so that's good and then if you
look at living with other exchange
students well one thing hey you get
friends from all over the world they're
all experienced the same thing is used
they're all learning and they all want
to go
or because we'll be the first time for
them seeing the Palacio al are going to
have tapas and things like that so it
can give you like a good friend base
when you're there buts that you're
hanging out with other exchange students
all the time it makes it harder for you
to meet locals okay nice especially one
of the benefits of living by yourself
you're forced to go and meet people and
when I've lived by myself
that's when my my best luck has been in
meeting new people from that country and
getting to know it better so there is
that one living an apartment and then
your third option is living in a dorm
now in the u.s. when you live in a dorm
it's probably on campus near your
buildings in Europe it's not always the
case when I did my masters in Berlin my
dorm was 45 minutes on the train to
school every day so it's not not
necessarily right there on campus now
some places do so make sure you ask
oh is this the is this the dorm that's
on campus near the school it'll make a
difference second thing that's good
about living on a dorm is you already
have all these students around you and
they're usually local students so you
get to know the culture you get invited
to the parties and all kinds of stuff
and the locals that are living in the
dorms they don't live with their parents
so they're from outside of the city
you're in so they're gonna go back to
their towns so you could go back with
them also they might not know many
people there so you get a chance to you
know I lived in Portugal and I was Ana
dorm for a bit and I got to meet
Portuguese people from Porto that were
living in Lisbon
so I got to be friends with them and go
do cool things with them back in Porto
and I'm a ver doing things like that
which was cool so you had that option
there now the downside of dorms is in
the u.s. you know you can have your
friends stay all the time Europe they're
a little bit stricter with the dorms and
who can come in and out and stuff like
that so that can be a little troublesome
okay so I hope that helped you get a

abroad and it really depends on what
